summary: This document is an email chain from April 2021 between the prosecution and defense teams in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). It details logistical negotiations for the defense to review physical evidence stored at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx and highly confidential electronic images, with the goal of arranging viewings for Maxwell and her legal team at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.role: Defense Attorney, Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.
persons.context: Lead defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with the prosecution to arrange evidence review logistics, raising issues about evidence access and transportation.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense team member copied on the email chain regarding evidence review arrangements.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Defense team member copied on the email chain regarding evidence review arrangements.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense team member copied on the email chain regarding evidence review arrangements.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case (US v. Maxwell). The emails discuss arrangements for her to be produced from MDC to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse to review evidence with her defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized evidence, including electronic devices, images, and videos from his residences that are subject to review.

connections.description: Menninger is a lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as shown by her advocacy for Maxwell's access to evidence.
Pagliuca is a member of Maxwell's defense legal team, copied on all strategic correspondence.
Everdell is a member of Maxwell's defense legal team, copied on all strategic correspondence.
Sternheim is a member of Maxwell's defense legal team, copied on all strategic correspondence.
The evidence being reviewed was seized from Epstein's residences and is part of the investigation into Maxwell, indicating their alleged association.
They are negotiating as opposing counsel in the case, with Menninger making requests and the AUSA setting conditions for evidence review.

events.title: Scheduled Bronx Warehouse Evidence Review
events.description: The defense team plans to send an attorney, investigator, and paralegal to review and photograph non-transportable evidence items at the FBI's Bronx warehouse.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Beginning of the evidence review at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, where Ghislaine Maxwell will be produced daily from MDC to review evidence with her defense team.

events.title: Defense Formal Request to View Evidence
events.description: Laura Menninger sent a formal letter requesting to view and inspect all materials designated as 'Highly Confidential' under the Protective Order.

events.title: Interview Recording Date
events.description: Reference to "one original recording of an interview dated 4/24/07" from the Florida evidence, which the defense questions the format of.

locations: 2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY (FBI Bronx warehouse)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York office)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office where cash evidence is held)
150 E. 10th Avenue, Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman law office)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell is held)
keyFacts: The FBI possesses a large volume of physical evidence stored at a warehouse in the Bronx, including items seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in 2019.
Approximately 2,100 electronic nude/partially nude images and videos seized from Epstein's devices had not been previously disclosed to the defense as of March 2021.

The defense negotiated for Ghislaine Maxwell to be physically present at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse to review evidence with her legal team, with the Marshals confirming production starting April 13, 2021.
Evidence includes sensitive categories like "Highly Confidential" images (which may not be photographed) and non-testifying witness statements on electronic media.
Logistical challenges included transporting bulky/fragile items, providing equipment to play old media formats (VHS, cassette, microcassette), and securing appropriate review space at the courthouse.
